name: Rothschild's Myna
description: It is pure white, with only a blue patch around the eyes.
spread_note: Western part of the Indonesian island of Bali
food_note: Fruits of various plant species, invertebrates
image_alt: Rothschild's Myna, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 16.5–17.5 cm; tail length 7.5–8.5 cm; weight 87–116 g
reproduction: Females lay 2–3 eggs; incubation lasts 13 days
attractions: It nests once a year, in February, during the rainy season. The nest is built in tree hollows, and both parents care for the eggs and young.
projects_note: Unable to adapt to other environments, any landscape alteration is catastrophic for it. Additionally, these mynas were heavily hunted for their appearance as ornamental cage birds. It’s no wonder only a few individuals remain in the wild, and the Rothschild’s myna survives only thanks to captive breeding. The current population is estimated at 500 individuals.
breeding: Rothschild’s mynas arrived at our zoo in 1975 from Durrell Zoo on Jersey, and the first successful breeding occurred in 1977. To date, over 190 chicks have hatched, most of which were successfully raised.
